Award.AwardTitle: Numerical Approximation of Joint Spectral Radius by Lower Rank Matrix Sets
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research program originates from a broad interdisciplinary study, combining mathematical and computational machineries to address a long-standing problem in the field of computational science, i.e., to approximate the joint spectral radius in an efficient way. Different from current approaches, in this project, the PIs propose an innovative approach via matrix rank decomposition. The main idea is to reduce the computational complexity through rank decomposition methodology so that desirable precision can be achieved. The proposed work will provide much needed common ground between theoretical study and computational approximation of joint spectral radius, and the research findings would effectively improve the existing approaches in literature, which in turn will lead to a valuable impact on applied sciences, such as system design and control in engineering and other related fields, as well as to better understandings of some long-standing open problems in mathematics. This project will provide mentorship and training for graduate and undergraduate students. Professional development of the students will be enhanced through mentoring activities which include broad training in mathematics and numerical analysis, guidance in oral and written communication, advice on career development, and dissemination of project results at national/international conferences.

The goal of this research project is to establish error bounds and to develop efficient algorithms for the computation and approximation of joint spectral radius by using lower rank matrix sets. The PIs will pay particular attention to the singular value decomposition, although other types of decompositions will also be explored, such as the rank decomposition from row echelon form obtained from Gaussian elimination. By using the concept of symmetric gauge function and its subdifferential, the joint spectral radius will be approximated through rank decompositions and the error bounds will be estimated by using generic vector norms. The proposed procedure for seeking a desirable gauge function is based on the rank approximation, allowing the minimization of its value at each step. Numerical algorithms will be established and are expected to provide effective computational tools to be applied to engineering and related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project mainly focuses on the study of the low rank approximations of the joint spectral radius for a given finite set of matrices with the same size. The joint spectral radius is a generalization of the classical notion of spectral radius of a matrix to sets of matrices, and has found applications in a large number of engineering fields. It characterizes the growth rate of matrix multiplications from a given finite matrix set, which provides fundamental implication for this matrix set associated with specific applications.  However, the joint spectral radius quantity itself is NP-hard to compute or to approximate in general. 

Matrix rank is an important characteristic in terms of matrix complexity. Thus low rank approximation becomes favorable, if approachable methods can be developed, from the computational point of view.  Associated with systems and control problems such as optimal control, observer design, matrix-valued Markovian process, chaotic behaviors of discrete linear inclusion systems, etc, we have developed corresponding approaches, in which the estimation of the joint spectral radius plays an important role there, mainly reflecting the system stability and instability. We further develop some approaches for higher order block tensor decomposition based on low rank characteristics by using the algebraic geometry theory. 

Intellectual Merit:

A sequence of problems related to the joint spectral radius, associated with systems and control problems, has been addressed. Thirty one (31) journal papers have been published or accepted to appear in addition to seven (7) published international conference papers during the award period. 

Broder Impacts:

1. Graduate Education: during the award period, we have developed two graduate topic courses: (i) Advanced Matrix Computations; (ii) Optimization, in PI's institute, offered to graduate students across the campus.  Four (4) Ph.D. and two (2) Master students, associated with this project, were graduated under the supervision of PI and Co-PI.  Two graduated Ph.D. students have been hired as tenured-track assistant professors at universities of the United States, one graduated Ph.D. works as a postdoc in a university of the United States, and another one has been back to his home country and worked as a faculty member in a university. Two master students have been working in the industry at US. 

2. Undergraduate Education: during the award period, PI also worked with an undergraduate student for a self-study of control theory. He currently is a graduate student in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at PI's institute. PI also developed a new undergraduate course: ``Mathematical Biology'' by working with colleagues in College of Science at PI's institute.

3. Outreaching Local Middle/High School Students: during the award period, PI has been offering math enhancement classes to local middle and high school students for every Saturday afternoon in both Fall and Spring semesters as a volunteer. In addition, PI has been worked with three (3) individual high school students for their mathematical projects. One of them entered the regional semifinal of Siemens Competition in the Fall of 2017. PI also served as the MATHCOUNTS coach for a local elementary school, and received the first place coach award in 2015, 2017, 2018, and second place coach award in 2016, respectively, in the Egyptian Chapter (Southern Illinois area). 

4. International Conferences: During the award period, the PI served for the program committees for the SIAM Conference on Control and Its Applications (C15) and (C17), respectively. The Co-PI organized a section on Matrix Theory, Computation, and Applications at Langenhop Lectures and Mathematics Conference at Carbondale, 2017.
